section.title: Default Beans
section.para: Suppose you have a situation where you want to provide a default implementation of a particular service and allow the user to override it as needed. Although this may sound like a job for JSR-299 alternatives, they have some limitations that may make them undesirable in this situation. If we were to use an alternative it would require an entry in every beans.xml file in the application. This means the end user may have to open up your jar file and edit the beans.xml file within, in order to override your service. They will also have to do this for every bean archive in their application, and if they miss one it will result in bugs. This is where default beans come in.
Default beans allow you to specify a default bean for a given bean type and set of qualifiers. If no bean is installed that has the same type and qualifiers then the default bean it installed.

Lets look at a real world example. Say we are writing a module to allow you to evaluate EL. If JSF is available we want to use the JSF provided FunctionMapper to resolve functions in EL, otherwise we just want to use a a default FunctionMapper implementation that does nothing. We can achieve this as follows:
If FunctionMapperProvider is present then it will be used by default, otherwise the default FunctionMapperImpl is used.

warning.para: Producer methods/fields and observer methods will not work on classes annotated @DefaultBean.
